trans-unit.source: Classes that derive from this abstract base class define geometric shapes.
Geometry objects can be used for clipping, hit-testing, and rendering 2-D graphic data.

## Geometry Compared to Shape The <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape?displayProperty=fullName> class has a <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape.Fill%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape.Stroke%2A>, and other rendering properties that Geometry and its derived classes lack.

The <xref:System.Windows.Shapes.Shape> class is a <xref:System.Windows.FrameworkElement> and therefore participates in the layout system; its derived classes can be used as the content of any element that supports <xref:System.Windows.UIElement> children.
The Geometry class, on the other hand, simply defines the geometry of a shape, and cannot render itself.
Because of its simplicity, it has a wider range of uses.

**Freezable Features:** Because it inherits from the <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> class, the Geometry class provides several special features: Geometry objects can be declared as , shared among multiple objects, made read-only to improve performance, cloned, and made thread-safe.
For more information about the different features provided by <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects, see [Freezable Objects Overview](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Rect"></xref> that specifies the axis-aligned bounding box of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.
This property does not take into account the area potentially added by a stroke.
The axis-aligned bounding box of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.
Creates a modifiable clone of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>, making deep copies of the object's values.
When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values.
This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object).
For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.Clone%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
A modifiable clone of the current object.

The cloned object's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen*> property will be <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> even if the source's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen*> property was <xref uid="langword_csharp_true." name="true." href=""></xref>
Creates a modifiable clone of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> object, making deep copies of the object's current values.
Resource references, data bindings, and animations are not copied, but their current values are.
This method is used to produce modifiable copies of frozen <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> objects (or any <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object).
For convenience, this method shadows the inherited version with a strongly typed implementation.
For more information, see <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.CloneCurrentValue%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
A modifiable clone of the current object.

The cloned object's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen*> property will be <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> even if the source's <xref:System.Windows.Freezable.IsFrozen*> property was <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
Combines the two geometries using the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GeometryCombineMode"></xref> and applies the specified transform to the resulting geometry.
This method uses the default tolerance factor (described by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) when combining geometries.
To specify your own tolerance factor, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Combine%2A> method.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Combine%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
Careful thought should be involved when using Combine to perform a union as it can be very CPU-expensive.
In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryGroup> or <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A> will work better.
Use Combine only when any of the following apply: - The geometric operation is not a union.

- Either of the geometries has a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> value of <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> and the geometries are self-intersecting (i.e. the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> actually matters).
- Time is not a concern, but space is (for instance, if the geometry is created once and then cached).
Typically, Combine produces smaller output than <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A>.
- The resulting geometry will be stroked or used in a path animation and <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A> does not provide the desired outline.
The first geometry to combine.
The second geometry to combine.
One of the enumeration values that specifies how the geometries are combined.
A transformation to apply to the combined geometry, or <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
The combined geometry.
Combines the two geometries using the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.GeometryCombineMode"></xref> and tolerance factor, and applies the specified transform to the resulting geometry.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Combine%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
Careful thought should be involved when using Combine to perform a union as it can be very CPU-expensive.
In most cases, a <xref:System.Windows.Media.GeometryGroup> or <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A> will work better.
Use Combine only when any of the following apply: - The geometric operation is not a union.

- Either of the geometries has a <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> value of <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> and the geometries are self-intersecting (i.e. the <xref:System.Windows.Media.FillRule> actually matters).
- Time is not a concern, but space is (for instance, if the geometry is created once and then cached).
Typically, Combine produces smaller output than <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A>.
- The resulting geometry will be stroked or used in a path animation and <xref:System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry.AddGeometry%2A> does not provide the desired outline.
The first geometry to combine.
The second geometry to combine.
One of the enumeration values that specifies how the geometries are combined.
A transformation to apply to the combined geometry, or <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometries.
Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
If `tolerance` is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"></xref> values that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of the geometry.
The combined geometry.
Gets an empty object.
The empty geometry object.
Indicates whether the current geometry completely contains the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.

The default margin of error (described by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) is used when determining whether the current geometry contains the specified geometry.
To specify your own margin of error, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.FillContains%2A> method.
The geometry to test for containment.
if the current geometry completely contains geometry; otherwise, .
Indicates whether the geometry contains the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Point"></xref>.

The default tolerance factor (described by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) is used when determining whether the geometry contains the specified point.
To specify your own tolerance factor, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.FillContains%2A> method.
The point to test for containment.
if the geometry contains hitPoint; otherwise, .
Indicates whether the current geometry contains the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>, given the specified margin of error.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.FillContains%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
The geometry to test for containment.
The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometries.
Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
If `tolerance` is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"></xref> values that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of the geometry.
if the current geometry contains geometry, given the specified margin of error; otherwise, .
Indicates whether the geometry contains the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Point"></xref>, given the specified margin of error.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.FillContains%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
The point to test for containment.

Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
If `tolerance` is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"></xref> values that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of the geometry.
if the geometry contains hitPoint, given the specified margin of error; otherwise, .
Returns a value that describes the intersection between the current geometry and the specified geometry.

The default tolerance factor (defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) is used when determining whether the current geometry contains the specified geometry.
To specify your own tolerance factor, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.FillContainsWithDetail%2A> method.

Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry"></xref> that is a polygonal approximation of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> object.
This method uses the default tolerance factor (described by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) when processing the geometry.

Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.

This method uses the default tolerance factor (described by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) when processing the geometry.
To specify your own tolerance factor, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.GetOutlinedPathGeometry%2A> method.

Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
A simplified outline of the filled region of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.

Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry"></xref>, within the specified tolerance, that is a simplified outline of the filled region of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.GetOutlinedPathGeometry%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.

Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometry.

A simplified outline of the filled region of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.
Returns an axis-aligned rectangle that is exactly large enough to contain the geometry after it has been outlined with the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref>.
This method uses the default tolerance factor (described by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) when processing the geometry.
To specify your own tolerance factor, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.GetRenderBounds%2A> method.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.GetRenderBounds%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
An object that describes the area of the geometry's stroke.
An axis aligned rectangle that is exactly large enough to contain the outlined geometry.

Returns an axis-aligned rectangle that is exactly large enough to contain the geometry after it has been outlined with the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref>, given the specified tolerance factor.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.GetRenderBounds%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
An object that describes the area of the geometry's stroke.
The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometry.
Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
If `tolerance` is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"></xref> values that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of the geometry.
An axis aligned rectangle that is exactly large enough to contain the outlined geometry.

Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry"></xref> that is the shape defined by the stroke on the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> produced by the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref>.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.GetWidenedPathGeometry%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
An object that describes the area of the geometry's stroke.
The outlined geometry.

Gets a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.PathGeometry"></xref> that is the shape defined by the stroke on the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> produced by the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref>, given the specified tolerance factor.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.GetWidenedPathGeometry%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
The object used to define the area of the geometry's stroke.
The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometry.
Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
If `tolerance` is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"></xref> values that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of the geometry.
The geometry, widened by pen.
Determines whether the object is empty.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the geometry is empty; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Determines whether the object might have curved segments.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the geometry object might have curved segments; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Creates a new <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> instance from the specified string using the current culture.
See [Path Markup Syntax](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md) for information about how this string is formatted
A string that describes the geometry to be created.
A new <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> instance created from the specified string.
Gets a value that indicates whether the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Transform*> property should be serialized.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the value of the geometry's <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Transform*> property should be serialized; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the standard tolerance used for polygonal approximation.
The standard tolerance, 0.25.
Determines whether the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Point"></xref> is contained in the stroke produced by applying the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref> to the geometry.

The default tolerance factor (specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) is used when determining whether the specified point is located in the geometry's stroke.
To specify your own tolerance factor, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StrokeContains%2A> overload.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StrokeContains%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
An object that determines the area of the geometry's stroke.
The point to test for containment.
if hitPoint is contained in the stroke produced by applying the specified to the geometry; otherwise, .

Determines whether the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Point"></xref> is contained in the stroke produced by applying the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref> to the geometry, given the specified margin of error.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StrokeContains%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
An object that defines the stroke of a geometry.
The point to test for containment.
The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometry.
Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
If `tolerance` is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"></xref> values that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of the geometry.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the stroke created by applying the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref> to the geometry contains the specified point, given the specified tolerance factor; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.

Returns a value that describes the intersection between the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> and the stroke created by applying the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref> to the current geometry.

The default tolerance factor (defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StandardFlatteningTolerance%2A> property) is used when determining whether the specified geometry is located in the current geometry's stroke.
To specify your own tolerance factor, use the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StrokeContainsWithDetail%2A> method.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StrokeContainsWithDetail%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.
An object that determines the area of the current geometry's stroke.
The geometry to test for containment.
One of the enumeration values.

Gets a value that describes the intersection between the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref> and the stroke created by applying the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Pen"></xref> to the current geometry, given the specified margin of error.
Some <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry> methods (such as <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.StrokeContainsWithDetail%2A>) produce or use a polygonal approximation of the geometry.
The tolerance factor specifies the maximum distance between points in this polygonal approximation.
Smaller tolerance values produce better approximations, but require more processing than an approximation with a large tolerance factor.

The geometry to test for containment.
The maximum bounds on the distance between points in the polygonal approximation of the geometries.
Smaller values produce more accurate results but cause slower execution.
If `tolerance` is less than .000001, .000001 is used instead.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.ToleranceType"></xref> values that specifies whether the tolerance factor is an absolute value or relative to the area of the geometry.
One of the enumeration values.
Formats the value of the current instance using the specified format.
The format to use.

-or- A null reference (<xref uid="langword_csharp_Nothing" name="Nothing" href=""></xref> in Visual Basic) to use the default format defined for the type of the <xref:System.IFormattable> implementation.
The provider to use to format the value.

-or- A null reference (<xref uid="langword_csharp_Nothing" name="Nothing" href=""></xref> in Visual Basic) to obtain the numeric format information from the current locale setting of the operating system.
The value of the current instance in the specified format.
Creates a string representation of the object based on the current culture.
A string representation of the object.
Creates a string representation of the object using the specified culture-specific formatting information.
Culture-specific formatting information, or <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref> to use the current culture.
A string representation of the object.
Gets or sets the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Transform"></xref> object applied to a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.
This method returns the identity transformation if the current object has no transformation value.
Otherwise, it returns the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Transform> applied to the current object.
## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|
The transformation applied to the <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Geometry"></xref>.

Note that this value may be a single <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Transform"></xref> or a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.TransformCollection"></xref> cast as a <xref href="System.Windows.Media.Transform"></xref>.
Identifies the <xref:System.Windows.Media.Geometry.Transform*> dependency property.
To be added.
